Award.AwardTitle: A Meeting of REU Site Directors in Astronomy
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is to support a meeting of directors of the Division of Astronomical Sciences (AST) Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Sites. The meeting will be held on May 19-20, 2014 in Flagstaff, Arizona, and will be hosted by the PI on the campus of Northern Arizona University, one of the AST REU sites. The intellectual merit of the meeting rests with the bringing together of site directors, current and new, to discuss successes and shortcomings in their own REU programs, and to establish best practices for future REU activities.

A major goal of the program is to foster ideas to achieve better success in recruiting minority students. Several people with specific expertise in minority-student recruitment will be invited to the meeting. Other topics include program evaluation, ethics, site management, and inter-program co-operation. The discussion of these issues will help broaden the impact of the AST REU portfolio, by improving the overall quality of the program, and making it more attractive to a broader range of students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award funded a meeting which brought together the directors of Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) sites currently funded by the NSF Division of Astronomical Sciences in order to discuss “best practices” for REU sites and to address issues of common concern. The discussion topics were generally described by two broad themes: the nuts and bolts of running a successful REU site, and brain-storming on better recruitment of under-represented minority students to our programs. We hosted two outside speakers from minority-serving universities who gave us their perspectives on how to better recruit such students. 

The intellectual merit of this award is in the scientific research that will be done by the students at these REU sites. One of the topics of discussion at the meeting was how to best structure student projects, which should increase the scientific output of the student participants.

The primary broader impact of the meeting was that it energized the site directors to increase the number of underrepresented minorities in astronomy REU programs. The percentage of minorities in astronomy is far too small, and most of the directors are eager to change that. One concrete outcome of the meeting was the formation of a subgroup to do “group” recruiting of minority students, i.e. recruiting for REU programs in astronomy in general, rather than one specific site. Another concrete outcome was the creation of an email group for the directors to stay in contact, as well as a common date for first offers each spring. Having a common date for first offers (March 1) ensures that students will be able to choose among program offers.

Another impact of the meeting is the professional development of the site directors. The directors of new sites (and newcomers to old sites) felt as though the information presented had saved them from making a lot of mistakes. Experienced site directors also found the meeting worthwhile; of particular interest were the discussions of program evaluation and of student professional development.
